review.title: Asymmetric separation for local independence graphs
review.abstract: Directed possibly cyclic graphs have been proposed by Didelez (2000) and Nodelmann et al. (2002) in order to represent the dynamic dependencies among stochastic processes. These dependencies are based on a generalization of Granger-causality to continuous time, first developed by Schweder (1970) for Markov processes, who called them local dependencies. They deserve special attention as they are asymmetric unlike stochastic (in)dependence. In this paper we focus on their graphical representation and develop a suitable, i.e. asymmetric notion of separation, called delta-separation. The properties of this graph separation as well as of local independence are investigated in detail within a framework of asymmetric (semi)graphoids allowing a deeper insight into what information can be read off these graphs.

sections.text: Directional, possibly cyclic graphs were proposed by Didelez (2000) and Nodelmann et al. (2002) to represent the dynamic dependencies between stochastic processes, which are based on a generalization of Granger causality to continuous time, first developed by Schweder (1970) for Markov processes, who called them local dependencies. They deserve special attention because they are asymmetrical. In this paper, we focus on their graphical representation and develop an asymmetrical notion of separation. The properties of this graph separation as well as local independence are studied in detail within a framework of asymmetrical (semi-) graphhoids that allow insight into what information can be gleaned from these graphs.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The classical graphical models and Bayesian networks represent (conditional) independence between random variables. They can be adapted to variables observed in discrete or discredited time, such as time series or Bayesian dynamic networks. However, this does not capture the intuitive notion of dynamic dependencies between processes that are asymmetrical, and we therefore propose an alternative. sections.heading: 5 DISCUSSION
sections.text: Local independence graphs and δ separation represent dynamic dependencies between continuous multi-stage processes and are a valuable tool for reasoning in dynamic environments of time-dependent confusion and censorship (Didelez, 2005a). Furthermore, the framework of asymmetric (semi-) graphhoids developed here can be applied more generally to asymmetric irrelevance relationships. Similar to the classical Bayesian networks, the graph structure can be used to simplify and accelerate calculations. In this context, some further results on the collapsibility and probability factorization in Didelez (2005a, 2005b) can be derived. Such probability of factoring is also used by Nodelman et al. (2003) to learn the graph.
